The rule does not require consent from the erroneously designated inventor (in this case, Ms Smith) for such a correction as long as it is done before publication or by the time the technical preparations are completed. Since no opposition was filed and the patent has only just been granted, the technical preparations have likely not yet begun, allowing the proprietor to make the necessary corrections.

- Explanation of why B is incorrect: Although no proceedings are pending at this moment, the EPO can still take action to correct the inventor designation based on Rule 60 before publication or upon the completion of technical preparations for publication.

- Explanation of why C is incorrect: While it might be common practice in some jurisdictions to require consent from all inventors for changes like deleting a name, there is no such requirement under EPC rules. The proprietor can unilaterally make corrections based on Rule 60 as long as the necessary time frame has not been exceeded.

- Explanation of why D is incorrect: As explained above, the EPO allows correction by the patent proprietor without needing consent from the erroneously designated inventor when making such changes before publication or during technical preparations.
